Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Resilient and Sustainable Engineered Fiber-Reinforced Earthen Masonry for High Wind Regions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research aims at experimentally and theoretically quantifying the structural resilience of a new fiber reinforced earthen masonry system for dwellings in high wind regions. This goal will be achieved by engineering and prototyping stabilized earth blocks and mortar, both enhanced with addition of natural fibers, and verifying the structural response of full-scale walls through physical testing. Engineering of the mortar and blocks will be based on two criteria: optimization of the amount of stabilizer and fibers, and compatibility of block and mortar where the target strengths are defined to force failure in the mortar joints. Engineering of the wall system will be based on the formulation and verification of interaction laws between applicable in-plane and out-of-plane forces. The interaction laws will be based on constitutive models obtained from the characterization of materials and scaled subassemblies. The collaboration involves faculty at the University of South Carolina, the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the University of Florida, with one PhD student at each institution. The engineering and characterization of the blocks and mortar will be lead by the University of Florida and the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, respectively. The engineering of the walls, including analysis and experimental verification, will be lead by the University of South Carolina, Columbia. The outcome will be a prototype block and mortar combination. The verification of the selected system will be based on proof-tests of full-scale wall specimens under in-plane, out-of-plane, and pendulum impact load simulating the impact energy of representative flying debris, which typically cause human deaths and injuries.

The proposed research will advance knowledge and technology by engineering both the mortar and blocks to enhance damage tolerance, and through the verification of structural system and predictive analytical models based on full-scale experiments. The final outcome of the project will be a novel, affordable, energy efficient and locally appropriate system for rural dwellings that is designed to withstand high wind loads, such as those experienced in the Midwestern and the Southeastern US. The outcomes of this project will be transferred to a broad audience of Indian reservations in Nebraska and to high-school students and teachers through a summer workshop program. New educational material will be incorporated in courses offered to engineering undergraduate and graduate students at the participating universities.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is an increasing demand for housing globally. This project’s ultimate goal was to show that, earth construction, which has traditionally been associated with dry climates and depressed socio-economic groups presents many benefits as a sustainable, affordable, and locally appropriate material and should be explored for wider use. The project team carried out an extensive experimental research program and studied the effects of soil type, stabilization type (lime or cement), stabilization percentage (5%-15%) and fiber addition on the structural and durability characteristics of compressed stabilized earth blocks (CSEBs) in tornado and hurricane prone areas. CSEBs can be made by using a manual or hydraulic press. The process is relatively easy and with a good machine, one block can be produced in a matter of minutes by one or two people. Our experiments included soil characterization, water absorption tests, tests to measure surface erosion under pressurized water (similar to wind and rain combinations), surface hardness, and compressive strength. Our key findings and suggestions are as follows.

  • A minimum of 6%, ideally 10% cement stabilization is necessary for soils that contain dispersive (highly erosive) clays.
  • When cement stabilized CSEBs are extremely strong against water and pressure.
  • More cement is not necessarily always better. At 15% cement stabilization, the curing of the blocks to a consistent strength becomes difficult.
  • Fiber addition has benefits in terms of overall material toughness and improvements in flexural (bending) capacity. However, there are no significant benefits for water absorption, compressive strength, and surface toughness.
  • Protrusion of fibers from the surface of the blocks or very large fibers (more than 2.5inches in length) should be avoided.
  • A tornado shelter and a high-wind resistant residential construction is possible with engineered earthen construction, however, thick wall sections and traditional steel reinforcement inside the wall cross-section (either between leaves of a multi-wythe wall or inside the core of the hollow CSEB, embedded with cementitious grout) must be considered.
  • For tornado resistant structures’ design, connections of the CSEB walls at the rood and foundation levels should also be taken into careful consideration to avoid problems due to uplift. 

 


Last Modified: 12/04/2015
Modified by: Ece Erdogmus

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: There is an increasing demand for housing globally. This projectÆs ultimate goal was to show that, earth construction, which has traditionally been associated with dry climates and depressed socio-economic groups presents many benefits as a sustainable, affordable, and locally appropriate material and should be explored for wider use. The project team carried out an extensive experimental research program and studied the effects of soil type, stabilization type (lime or cement), stabilization percentage (5%-15%) and fiber addition on the structural and durability characteristics of compressed stabilized earth blocks (CSEBs) in tornado and hurricane prone areas. CSEBs can be made by using a manual or hydraulic press. The process is relatively easy and with a good machine, one block can be produced in a matter of minutes by one or two people. Our experiments included soil characterization, water absorption tests, tests to measure surface erosion under pressurized water (similar to wind and rain combinations), surface hardness, and compressive strength. Our key findings and suggestions are as follows. A minimum of 6%, ideally 10% cement stabilization is necessary for soils that contain dispersive (highly erosive) clays. When cement stabilized CSEBs are extremely strong against water and pressure. More cement is not necessarily always better. At 15% cement stabilization, the curing of the blocks to a consistent strength becomes difficult. Fiber addition has benefits in terms of overall material toughness and improvements in flexural (bending) capacity. However, there are no significant benefits for water absorption, compressive strength, and surface toughness. Protrusion of fibers from the surface of the blocks or very large fibers (more than 2.5inches in length) should be avoided. A tornado shelter and a high-wind resistant residential construction is possible with engineered earthen construction, however, thick wall sections and traditional steel reinforcement inside the wall cross-section (either between leaves of a multi-wythe wall or inside the core of the hollow CSEB, embedded with cementitious grout) must be considered. For tornado resistant structuresÆ design, connections of the CSEB walls at the rood and foundation levels should also be taken into careful consideration to avoid problems due to uplift.
